content:
17
												I downloaded rift recently, while itching to play an mmo where I could sling spells from a distance and had some nice bredth of classes.Playing as a 'Reaper,' on the both fronts I was not disappointed. Although the information on Rift's website is rather vague and the wiki isn't much better, there's a satisfying depth to each 'calling.' Callings are your basic fantasy classes of Mage, Rogue, Warrior and Cleric. Within these 'callings' there are a variety of skill trees, of which the player may choose three, although there are in-game guides to help the player with recommended combinations which synergise well. You may also change which three 'soul trees' you're using and redistribute points, when not in combat.After your beginning instance, you're let out into the world to do you generic WoW-esque questing. Some small villages centre on teaching you about skills like fishing and survival or crafting professions. One introduces you to 'dimensions,' which are basically small home instances for you to decorate, although figuring out how to get there requires fumbling through various interfaces. W/r dimensions, the ability to rotate and adjust objects on xyz axes is nice and it's pretty smooth too.The negative aspects are however, quite significant. The questing system, graphical style and f2p model feel very reminiscent of various Asian f2p mmorpgs, which are lagging behind in the genre somewhat. In this regard, the game feels very same-y, there's not much I can get from it that I couldn't get from ArchAge or Jade Dynasty, the prior of which has cool things like boats, trans-continental trade and pvp against pirates at sea, to make it stand out some more.Like a f2p Asian mmo, Rift also suffers from the over-zealous use of premium currencies, boosts and other micro-transactions that we're all familiar with by now. As other reviews have pointed out, throwing money at the game gives you the ability to bypass a lot of the levelling(which makes up a lot of the content) and removes a lot of the grind. Not to mention that small cosmetic changes, like changing hair or character's gender costs thousands in this currency. Saving up for your first mount is instead chump change, if you choose to buy premium currency, something which I feel cheapens many aspects of the game. Rift is not shy about advertising patronship to the player either, including a button which is visible on-screen at all times, unless the player deliberately changes the ui layout to conceal it.The dimension home-instances seem like another way to squeeze money out of the player, by encouraging them to purchase furniture using premium currency, as much of the items above-beginner level became substantially more expensive.Lastly, although there's a sustantial effort made to explain how the 'soul tree' skill tree system works, there are other areas of the game which require more explanation. A number of quests required that I craft say a fishing lure, but gave no explanation as to how to do that. Instead, I had to read through the dialogue to find instructions clearly added in after much player confusion and frustration. Granted, I would have seen this had I read the dialogue the first time, but so much of the questing was so very boring and outdated that I had little motivation to really care about why I was collecting 10 Mutated Meat or killing 8 undead. Again, there's little information on either the website or the wiki, regarding this.I don't have anything against the game, nigh pay-to-win features aside, but it's just not very good. If it wasn't f2p I wouldn't have played it at all and I have a hard time believing people once willingly paid a continual subscription to experience Rift. The good features of the game are unfortunately drowned out by the more generic or out-dated aspects and what enjoyment I did get out of it, quickly drew to a close.

content:
r 29, 2016
												Please note the hours I have put into this game. I've been playing for 3 years now, and I am very particular about MMOs. I also don't like to spend money without justification. The only money I spend in RIFT on a regular basis is when I feel like I want to buy a new mount or some kind of consumable. You don't have to pay anything to enjoy this game or have access to the content.I have played most of the content solo, but it is much faster and more fun if you have friends to play with you. One of the new features Trion has implemented is sorting new players into starter guilds (defiants or guardians) on each server (shard). This helps new players find other players, so don't stress about being lost.There are many people in the game, despite other statements in the reviews. Many of the older, larger guilds have died out, but there are lots of smaller, newer ones that are active and growing. Find them and you'll find the happy, thriving player base that makes the game enjoyable.You don't have to buy the Soul packs to play effective character builds. You don't have to be a patron to get things accomplished -- it just expedites some tasks and adds conveniences. You don't have to have full raid gear. Trion has simplified many facets of the game in the time I have played it, mostly for the betterment and greater enjoyment of the game. If you feel like you DO need to buy the soul packs and expansion goodies, wait until there's a sale. You can get everything you want for a fraction of the price if you don't suffer from instant gratification issues.Immerse yourself in the story-rich world of Telara. Explore everywhere. Talk to NPCs. Delve into the Achievements to find fun rewards for doing things that aren't in your quest log. I hope to see you in the game!

(this is good or bad depending how you look at it) end game gear is only $400 if you want to be "competitive"6)the rift engine is still unstable even with the new fix and you sometimes get dc'ed normally when your winning a pvp match.so what about end game raiding?well do to rushed content most end game raids are bugged for month upon release and sometimes forever after(there are still bad bugs in content made when rift first came out). they are also removing hardcore raids but not to make rift mainstream (like wow did) but do to rushed content people can not beat the bugged content without making it easier also if your a streamer and stream raid content you run the risk of a guild wide ban if you do something the devs don't like or if you have an "agitator" in your group. for normal dungeons again do to low population and a change to the que system no ones does these untill end game and at end game people just want a fast run.you can do open world pve untill 60 with little to no issues but at 65 the paywall will smack you in the face. open world pvp is dead and the one pvp server is barren.the game used to be so good with a great f2p model but 6 months back they changed to an aggressive cash shop model and now rush all content before proper testing can be done that will normally crash the server like last week when it was down for 2 day because they didn't test the holiday updates or just leave some things outright broken for months untill they get around to patching it. some holiday events even have the same bug pop up every year that never gets fixed like a Halloween quest that doesn't give defiants the reward. sadly this game was a hallmark for a good f2p model but has now gone the way of the other rippoff f2p games.p.s. there is a item in game that lets you buy credits with in game gold but the amount you need to get is very hard to amass since alot of end game things give little to no cash (about 30% only give 1 silver and thats the lowest amount possible)

												Its p2win.  Sure, you can technically get the gear for "free," but its "grind tokens for a month for one piece of gear" levels of grind.  There are also rare-ish drops in the over-tuned flashpoints that are equivalent to the token purchases.  What this does is encouraging p2win on the left and an obscenely toxic community on the right.  I tried to get back into rift recently, and I had to quit the 5th time I got ♥♥♥♥ed over by a pug for loot.  I'm not so sure how prevalent this was across servers, but the pay-wall and cross-server PUGS (extra-layer of anonymity) encourages it greatly. I'm not just talking about "but the tank took my dps gear/he already got a piece!" whining (although that was horrendously common).   My "favorite" was when a particularly nice weaopn drops, and the entire group rolls against me for it with the intention of preventing me from winning and having a GM transfer it to their friend, the other rogue.  ♥♥♥♥ me for successfully healing a tough HM dungeon, right? They even told me to stfu because he naturally won the roll (and for the record, he already got loot too). This also ignores the people that demand you be overgeared to do any content, or try to get carried and wipe the group while not even wearing the starter crafting gear for HM's with some reputation items.  No enchants, no enhancements, no effort.  So success rate in even getting the pre-raid gear to drop was low enough.  Then you had to pray your group doesn't stab you in the back for it when it does.So never play it without friends and/or immediately leave a group if you see ~3-4 people from the same guild in there with you.  THey will close ranks and ♥♥♥♥ you over due to the cut-throat P2W formula the game has set up.  Its at least a 50/50, but my experience was a lot worse.That and its basically all just reskinned content.  Oh look, more of the same! just over and over.

content:
r 16, 2014
												4.5/5 RIFT is a free to play MMO with a familiar (Warcraft) feel to it, that does enough to distinguish itself from all the other f2p MMOs out there.Pros:- The class system has been designed with flexibility in mind. Every class has the ability to switch roles, so you could be tanking in a dungeon one minute and doing solo quests as a DPS the next. MMO newbies can play with preset skill-trees to avoid being overwhelmed, whilst MMO veterans can tinker away with custom builds to their heart's content.- Dynamic zone events. You can be quietly questing in a zone, when suddenly, rifts open up spawning mobs and eventually, the event boss.  This encourages everyone in a zone to band together to close rifts and take down the boss, which is great fun.- How you choose to level up is really flexible. Do quests, instant adventures (kill/fetch quests with other players), zone events or dungeons.- RIFT is still actively being developed. Version 3.0 is due soon (end of Otober 2014)- Once you hit lvl 50, a new skill tree system (planar attunement) opens up, offering more customisation. A special set of dungeons (Chronicles) designed for 1-2 playes also becomes accessible from lvl 50+.- If want to try dungeons (designed for 5 players) but haven't got guild friends to join with, you can join a dungeon queue that will automatically match 5 random players together. (Note: the wait time depends on your role, it seems that tanks are in short supply, followed by healers)Cons: - Quests can get a bit grindy sometimes; many are of the "collect 20 of .."  or "kill 12 of ..." variety. However, occasionally you do come across more fun/unusual/interesting/innovative quests, lifting the game above your standard MMO.- Some zones are not well optimized and FPS will suddenly drop from a smooth 60fps down to 20fps. - Free players can buy stuff from the auction house but can't sell (although there is a trade chat channel available). It is possible however to use in-game currency (plat) to buy something called REX that another player has paid for using real cash. The REX can be used to unlock the ability to sell in the auction house.Recommendation: If you want to experience the fun and familiarity of an MMO like Warcraft, but don't want to pay a monthly subscription, then RIFT will provide exactly what you are looking for. It is a well-designed, flexible game ... and did I mention it was free?

												I'm sitting, currently, at about +1000 hours, with four max level characters, so I feel that I have a sound understanding of the game. I am also a former WoW, GW2, PW, and other MMOs player. That being said lets dive into it. 6.9/10Pros:Leveling to max level is easy.Crafting is really easy to understand.Souls are different and easy to swap between.Your bags are almost never full (unless you have a hording problem)PvP can be enjoyable.Pugs are rather realible.The community is mostly friendly.You don't really need a guild until max level.Everyone can be everything.Cons:Some aspects of the game take a long time and a lot of focus to get. EX: you need 4kish Void Stones to buy an upgrade component to upgrade your gear. It takes a while to get the Void Stones and it becomes rather grindy.It's overall rather grindy. Grind raids, grind pvp, grind dungeons.. That's all max level is..Getting multiple characters geared takes a long time so your better off just having one main and not really playing the other classes.You NEED to raid to get gear at high levels.. You need raid gear to tank the dungeon to get the raid gear.The PvP maps get really stale after the hundreth time you've seen them and the dev's don't really seem to care.There are only two conquest maps, and I really only see one anymore.The dungeons are also very repeative and the low level dungeons become quickly tiresome.They've tried to make instant adventures better but they still make you want to peel your skin off after an hour or two.Also they aren't adding more free hairstyles. :(It's a pretty ok game, just try to ignore how some of the races look when they run with weapons or swing their weapons. I noticed it and now I can't stop watching the way my warrior swings her sword..

number of helpful: 15 of 19 people (79%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
er 5, 2016
												This review is current as of 12/5/16.Where do I start? I've had loads of fun playing RIFT (about 5k hours, just over half through Steam) and do not regret a single moment. I started playing during Beta 1 (though I had proximity to the game's development prior), and from the Eye of Regulos to Ashenfell, it's been a wild ride. The rifts are what make the game world different from other MMOs. They're dynamic events that can appear throughout a zone in a number of locations - in 6 different types as well as variations of the rifts within those types. I still have yet to finish all of the planar achievements, and it's been almost 6 years.Then there's the soul system. While some souls are paid for (3 per class/calling), the combinations you can make with them are only limited by your imagination. There is an argument to be made that the cookie-cutter specs you can find on the official forums are currently better, and that does detract from the original "any spec, any time" aspect of the game. Some specs are simply not viable in endgame content, like Druid was for clerics for a long time.The community appears at first to be a mixed bag, but the chat is filled with a vocal minority of trolls. Ignore them and carry on, and you'll find that there are plenty of nice and welcoming players in the game. I'd suggest turning off the CrossEvents channel if you don't care for what political rant there is that week.PvE content? There's no shortage of that - between questing, rifts, planar invasions, dungeons, and raids (past, current, or upcoming), I doubt you'd find a way to finish all of it amazingly fast. Even with store experience boosts.PvP - it's always been a bit lacking, but it really took a hard hit after Nightmare Tide (Patch 3.0), when PvP-specific gear was removed. Low-level warfronts (Rift's battleground system) take upwards of an hour or two to get a queue to pop, and Conquest has been dead for a while (until it gets updated with current rewards). However, max-level warfronts are still alive and kicking and have a different meta to them than PvE content as far as specs go.And the big question - is Rift P2W? Nope. Rift, if I had to sum it up, is "pay-to-progress-faster", but nothing will ever give you a solid gameplay advantage long-term in Rift other than the loyalty system (extra mount speed is nothing to sniff at). Most of what is in the store is either fluff or used to get alts to max level (currently 70) faster. With Starfall Prophecy, all content after level 65 is locked unless you buy the expansion pack, but a trial to 65 out of 70 levels with nothing to lose on the way is amazing, compared to other MMOs that limit you to level 20.There is, however, a significant time investment required - in the form of reputation grinds (I use the term loosely), gearing up through the various tiers (which reset every expansion pack), and money in general (Planar Fragments in Starfall Prophecy being a particularly hard platinum sink). Don't let that deter you from the game - after all, none of these time-investment-specific requirements apply to the level 1-65 content, which is entirely free with no timegating!If you have more questions about the game, you can find me on the North America region servers: Maladii@Faeblight.

content:
r 8, 2015
												Pros:-It's free. You can't go wrong with free games. Get bored? Leave for as long as you want and come back whenever you want. You don't have to worry about paying for a month or so of game time when you only want to play for a day.-Thanks to Rift Exchanges, which people sell for in game money, you can buy everything including expansions without paying a single penny.-You can transfer characters between shards (servers) for free, but there is a limit to how many you can do in a week.-You can temporarily move the character you're playing to another shard without limit, though you will return once you log out of that character.-If you have no friends who play this that you can quest with, you can just join "instant adventures" which will automatically join you to a raid group. You will even be brought up or down to the level of the group's quests temporarily.-If you want to go back and do a certain dungeon but you're too high of a level to normally be in a group, the game will automatically bring you down to the level of that group.-This game is in no way pay to win. Everything you can buy you can earn the equivalent of. No one class is really better than another. Also like I said above, you can buy absolutely everything with in game money.Cons:-Not a lot of people are low level so you might have a hard time finding a group in your level range, and it is very hard to find a group to do dungeons with.-That's about it.

content:
16, 2015
												This may have been one of the better MMO's out there.  They took what was good about WOW, and in some cases improved upon it.  Crafting/combat and professions are decent.  The lore and background writing are very good.  Questing isn't too much of a grind.  Graphics are quite good also. The problem?  You can play for free, but it's tough.  Extra bank slots, etc. cost money.  You have to have credits/REX to purchase these things and boy do they make sure that EVERYTHING can be upgraded for a price.  You can buy REX with ingame money, but it takes a lot of platinum and that takes a lot of time to earn.  Now I got the monthly subscription for $15 a month.  Turns out it just gives you some perks that really aren't that helpful.   It does not increase your bank vault, etc.  You STILL have to buy credits to do that.  So the subscription is not really worth it.  Now I could live with the cash shop mentality and just spend the $15 on credits rather than the subscription.  That would be the better choice in my opinion.  You're still getting a high quality game for your money.  The DLC's are another story though.  Drastically overpriced.  $150 for the Ultimate Nightmare edition?  I played a character up to level 35 and was enjoying it, but the fact that nonPVP is not an option turns me off.  Getting constantly griefed by a 60+ over and over is not fun.  Especially since the server was touted as PVE/RP.   Apparently that makes no difference and every server is set up the same, no matter what it says.  I would happily pay for the game if I had the option to actually have a co-op role playing type experience, but sadly that's not available here.  Conclusion.   If you're looking for a mature, role-playing game to enjoy and not be all about who's the biggest imaginary badass, then this is not the game for you. P.S. The coarse and racist language on the chat is pretty bad.  Doesn't seem to be moderated at all.

number of helpful: 23 of 36 people (64%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
13, 2015
												6/10I started playing RIFT before it was even full release. (Like many I used the executable/patcher to launch outside of steam even after release. Until I had to reinstall when SL patching messed up, so... that piddly 1k is time after SL only.)RIFT 'was' an awesome game with good support and a REALLY awesome community. The game had alot of elements, which were in it, were going to be in it, some of which no other MMO's had at the time. In my eyes it was akin to an attempt at the 'Next Generation' of MMO.The game evolved and grew over the first 2 years, it had it's share of bugs and problems, but they worked hard and got things sorted out quickly and fairly.The problems started, when Trion or the development group decided to do an 'expansion', one huge bundle of content to put them far ahead and allow them to evolving the game without having to struggle so much to keep up (Atleast I thought that's why they did it...).Following this decision there was a major slowing of evolution/updates/content. It was expected, and yet it had bad results.During the 'Lull' in content, alot of players fell away and some guilds either merged or died out.When the 'Storm Legion' expansion finally came out, it did help revitalize the community 'somewhat', but with the 'X was the first to' seekers and the massive hunger resultant from the break in content, alot of new content got chewed through by some in a matter of days.After the initial burst of players, the population went back to, or maybe even more low than before, with even more guilds merging or dissolving.Trion decided then to re-vitalize the player base by going Free-to-play. (*Demise music plays)About 3 days after the game went FTP the general chat went from asking for an extra for a raid or new players asking for help to something akin to trolls vs gold spammers. Sure there was idle chat and such before, but nowhere near the same magnitude....Going into a random when guildies are offline, meant having an overgeared party that doesn't know/use mechanics and ignores when told, won't use interrupts or help skills out of fear of DPS loss or who knows what and then rages at the healer when they die from their stupidity despite being over geared. Sure you get good parties too, but it went from more like 4/5 with 1 of the 4 being a 'learning' party, to 2/3 with 1 undergear, 1 overgear and 1 drop/lame, to like 1/6 with 1 being OP and playing right and 5/6 still being OP, but being macro only players who only do DPS and can't move or insist on having 1 only macro with built in 'dispel magic' type abilities and still stand still, both of which have primary skill called 'rage healer or tank and DC'. Well, PUGS always had atleast a small gamble element, and there were still plenty of 'good community'. A mature player might have to scroll through 50 lines of text to find a question and 'whisper' a new player to help, but the help was still there.I stayed for a while and played in some of the decent guilds, but even some of those had troubles from bad players joining and having to be kicked or just getting freebies then leaving. I know of many large kind/good/fun guilds that ended up moving to Badlands, Star Wars MMO's and who knows what else. (I think one even went back to WOW...)FTP has not wrecked the game. All the higher tier items and things are not buyable, and there is still some good guilds with nice/mature people in them around, so that raiding can still be fun. Sadly, although the FTP element has been implemented reasonably, I can ohonestly say the move has certainty affected the type of in-game community that's there unfavourably. I would not be surprised if the servers ended up reduced to only 1 or 2. Support in the same boat as FTP hasn't wrecked the game or made it unplayable, but has certainly affected the community in a negative way.Trion changed the handling/personnel of the game around the time of the SL expansion (Not long after release I think it was...)The original support was almost instantaneous in-game and up to 48 hrs outside of, and was very fair in checking logs and being strict but properly compensating and helping.The support now seems more like 72hrs in-game and 1-2weeks outside of (I had patron status if that makes any difference -> AVID trader AH user/trader). And the support became more like talking to a telesales/outsourced helpdesk or the like where you couldn't even be sure if they even knew what the game was called, let alone help or not give 'bad robot' responses.The first big event with a death boss was a good example of this. When I tried to get to the boss it was SO chunky and the game crashed about 2 mins after I finally got there. Sounds bad.... but Trion did patches and within a day or two the event was back up and running I got to participate with only minimal lag during the boss fight. Players were also compensated if they attended the initial event just incase they couldn't re-attend on short notice.From what I heard the last time a big crash occured recently in RIFT, they just rolled back the servers 6 days instead of fixing. :O I wasn't on at the time, but well... I can totally understand some of the angst that's there.If your an original player who loved the game for having good support the current level will likely hit you like a truck full of concrete. Having said that, it doesn't wreck the game, but it sure doesn't make you wanna play/pay/support it.New players be sure to try the game, it has lots of story and content to explore especially if you don't skip the lower levels....For old players... RIFT is like any other thing in life that gets broken... it can never go back to the way things were. You either have to put up with the junk that goes with it or just leave it alone...

content:
er 3, 2013
												I played Rift since the beta, I usually play rift without steam so I could've gotten more hours on record but anyway, rift. This game doesn't really have a good first impression but once you get the feel of it, it gets addicting and can be a legitimite replacement for what ever MMO you are playing now. (WoW.. Cough.) It has a unique class system that pulled me right away when I was playing in the beta. The balancing of the classes are mostly turned towards the PvE side of the game. PvP you ask?.. Well, PvP isn't Rift's strong suit... at all. While it can still be fun, the imbalances can make it frustrating and the enormous amount of 'bad' players can really make you bite your lip. I feel as though rift's PvP is more balanced for group play than solo. Also Facerolling is quite common, so it's best to bring a pre-made party. The PvE side of this game though is exellent, it really makes you think what is the best spec for each situation you are in. Actually, the class system makes the game, it is very good. Once you are starting this game, it is wise to not stick to one build; make a TON of them and make the right spec you see fit to your tastes and works in your favor. There is a lot of things going on the map at all times. Rifts, are a key machanic which the name of the game implies. They pop randomly on the map and when you complete one you could get some wonderful goodies in return. An other cool thing are invasions that wonder across the map, making the game feel alive. But during an event, these invasions can get hairy and could literally conquer a whole area. Your quest hubs will be invaded and even main cities. This encourages group play which is very nice as well. You'll usually be grouped up automatically and fight against the baddies is some type of full blown war.Speaking of wars, this game is pretty CPU intensive so big wars might make you lag, a lot. Any good mid ranged GPU will run this game well but don't skimp on the CPU, god help you if you don't. I would love to write more but I am pretty busy at the moment, it was nice to test this steam grading system out.PS: The ingame store is pretty nice, they put a lot of work into it. Also nothing in the store will give you SUPER MAX ENDGAME MEGA GEARZ. It's mostly costumes and funiture for your ingame home. The lockboxes don't have anything worthwhile inside, though it is good for gamblers or whatever.

number of helpful: 18 of 27 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
31, 2016
												First off, I've played this game for hundreds of hours outside of Steam. I have 2 max level characters.The people who think the game is P2W haven't looked deep enough. The shop is deceiving at first glance. It shows the highest tier armor for sale for real-world currency only. What you don't see, is how to get that armor in-game for free.The highest tier (raid) armor is achieved by UPGRADING lower tier (dungeon) armor, which you CAN do for free (quite easily in fact) OR from buying it directly in the shop for real-world currency. The game is not pay-2-win, it's pay-2-skip. You can either take the time to get geared yourself or skip past that and go straight to raids.Now that that's out of the way, the game itself is pretty easy to describe. It's a F2P WoW clone. It looks like WoW, it plays like WoW, it feels like WoW. I've never played another "WoW clone" that gave me this feeling I never knew I was missing since I stopped playing WoW.That's not to say that it doesn't have it's differences. The class system is amazingly customizable. Put simply, remember the talent trees in WoW, pre-Cataclysm? In Rift you can mix and match the three talent trees from 11 trees per class. Mix Warlock with Stormcaller and Frostkeeper as a mage, or Marksman with Bard and Assassin as a rogue. Make familiar classes like WoW-style Warlock by mixing Warlock (affliction) with Necromancer (demonology) and Pyromancer (destruction).There are other innovations as well, far too many to go into in this review. However, none of them keep the game from playing like WoW.TL;DR: If you're looking for a F2P WoW replacement, this is by far your best option. It is also not P2W though it may appear so at first glance.

												Rift is by far one of my favorite MMORPG games I have played in many years. It has a great leveling system and a customizable abilities and skill point tree system. It has a customizable UI/HUD and many positive points. Now I do have a few problems with the game. But that is with all mmo's. The mob spawn rate is a little fast for the amount of travel for the missions. Also it is now A FtP game and that makes it a little bias cause we as free players are stuck with lower stuff and I understand that but there should be a way for us to get the same stuff without a sub. All in all a fantastic game i recommend to everyone

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
2016
Grind Till Ya DropOverviewAfter tapping both the "Yes" and "No" buttons several times in response to the question "Do you recommend this game?" I realized that I'm kind of indecisive about the whole thing. My view on it is completely torn down the middle. In some ways, Rift is incredible. In other ways, it's downright terrible. In the end, I find that "fifty percent" isn't enough to recommend the game. I have to say, sorry, but you should pass on this one. But don't leave without reading why I think so. There's a lot of ground to cover.Before you comment on this, I reinstalled the game on the Glyph launcher and stopped playing it through Steam. It might not track my hours correctly, but I have been playing for about 3/4s of a year.What I liked about the game:1) RIFT borrows heavily from WoW, especially early iterations of it. The UI is the same, the cooldown and GCD system is exactly the same, the crafting, the queueing for dungeons and battlegrounds-- I'm sorry, "warfronts"-- the talent trees (again, this is more like early WoW, not the garbage "three choice blocks" WoW has nowadays), the combat, the classes, and even the stats each character needs is strikingly similar to WoW. If you've played WoW, you can pick up RIFT very easily.2) The talent trees are intuitive and creative, because they can be customized. You can have a build-your-own-spec based on three trees you can pick from and place points in. This makes for a very fun experience in creating your own class. Many of the best specs in the game were found by other players just messing around with the custom talent trees.3) There is something in the game called "Instant Adventures," a sort of endless barrage of instanced questing zones that you can enter with 20-something people. It's the dungeon instance 2.0, and works great. Well, while you're leveling, anyway. After you're max level, they're obsolete.4) The graphics are breathtaking and realistic. I definitely prefer it over WoW's cartoonish style.What I didn't like about the game1) At first I thought to say "This game is well-populated" but then I forgot that only two servers really are. The rest are deadzones, especially the oceanic server. If you play in the UK... you will be forced to play on a North American server, in timezones opposite of you. That... sucks.1) At 65 (the current max level) the game sort of... halts. You will not be getting into raids very soon, and I can guarantee you that. You know why? Because you need a certain amount of "hit rating." This is RIFT's equivalent of "item level," except to an insanely unfair degree. The grind for gear is literally endless, and not at all fun. The methods to obtain gear may also be totally obscure to you when you ding 65, as it was for me. There is no set path to take. You might get gear by either winning warfronts (and no, you can not buy gear with the tokens you obtain from warfronts-- you have to get it from the box), or by doing what is called "Nightmare Tide Expert Dungeons" which are exactly that-- a nightmare. Neither of these things are the least bit fun to do, so naturally, it seems even worse when you're doing them just to upgrade gear.Now, when I say you might get gear, that's because gear isn't guaranteed to drop in the box you get for winning a warfront. You have a chance at it. And if you're like me, you will lose so many games that the chance at gear is even lower than average. I have so many unspent favor ("honor") points because none of it goes toward anything special. Apparently, people tell me that I will use them later to "upgrade" my new gear I get from the boxes from winning warfronts. And it takes tens of thousands of these tokens just to do that. And yes... you HAVE to upgrade them, because otherwise you won't have enough hit on your gear to do raids... or anything else. So even after you get the pieces you need, you still have to lose hundreds of warfronts, get tokens, upgrade all the pieces... it's awful. God awful.So, you don't like to PvP? Okay! Do NTEs instead. And wipe constantly on bosses. When you finally do about twenty painful dungeons and get a piece of gear you need, you have to also upgrade THAT with tokens. But not with the PvP tokens. You need "fragments". These rare, coveted Fragments of Darkness and Fragments of Madness are mostly obtained through daily dungeons queues and months and months of weekly quests. I say you'll be doing them for months, because that's how long it'll take you just to upgrade a few pieces of your gear. It is the most sluggish, hellish, most boring end-game I've ever played in my life. It isn't even an "end game". It's just grinding gear. "End game" should imply being able to do things at the end of the game.Because of this boring charade, most guilds are casual, because they're forced to be. There do exist raiding guilds, but progression is so slow that you never hear a thing about them.More than one person in RIFT has explained this to me: "Trion Worlds made the grind so long because they want you to give up and shell out the dough to buy all of the gear for credits". At first I thought "that makes no sense," but now... it kind of does. You can buy gear with real money in RIFT-- for hundreds of dollars. No average-income Joe can just buy the gear and P2W because it's so expensive. But over months of time... an impatient person could very well buy the gear they need one piece at a time, and it all adds up. I already know a few people that dumped real money on gear pieces because the grind is so bad. I think what they're saying is true. It's all because of greed.And no... being a patron ("subscriber") does not help with this. You have to grind it out just as much as the freebies do. Which brings me to my next gripe:2) Patron status sucks. I get nothing for being a patron exect a crappy weekly "gift" (usually a trove box with junk in it worth nothing) and something called "affinity"-- yet another type of currency stacked upon the already massive mountain of currencies in the game. Affinity buys you mostly casual, cosmetic crap, and very few things that improve your character. Yes, patrons get bonuses toward mount speed and experience... but the increase isn't by very much, so it's not worth it. You also get "loyalty" for spending real money in the game. Loyalty also gives you mostly-cosmetic junk. No gear, though. Or anything else that might be useful.3) Notoriety ("reputation") grinds. Because having to grind out a faction's rep on top of grinding for gear and grinding for crafting mats adds to the fun!4) Dream orbs. You remember enchants in WoW? Okay, think of those, but only imagine they once in a while gave you a useless stat on your gear that means nothing to you, so that you're forced to sink hundreds of gold on them to get the stat you need. Sounds like crap, doesn't it? Well, that's because it is.5) Lockboxes and troves. Trion will dangle rare prizes in your face in hopes that you're stupid enough to drop a hundred bucks on these "limited editions troves" they release. They do that by showing you this sparkly, awesome mount that can be won inside. The chance at getting these mounts is extremely low. It's been tested a few times by people with even more time on their hands than I. You'd have to buy over a hundred boxes at five bucks a piece. Come to find out, people are stupid enough to buy these, so they keep making them. Keep it up, RIFTers. Keep being part of the problem.6) Plat is hard and slow to earn unless you spend real money on tradeable creditsFinal Thoughts"Gear-grinding" is used as "game content" in place of real game content.

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
er 18, 2015
												RIFT is a free-to-play MMORPG (Massively Multiplayer Online Roleplaying Game. Wow what a mouthful) set in the plane of Telara, a typical Tolkienesque fantasy world with a twist.Both playable factions are arguably good and arguably evil. The Guardians are religious and magic-centred, and despise the technological Defiants, whose machines they see as blasphemy. And this is where you come in; as an Ascended warrior, brought back from the dead to fight the corruption of the Dragons and the sinister Regulos, who want to destroy Telara to save the other planes.You will be sent back in time in a Terminator-esque plot to stop the invasion of Telara when it starts - when the rifts came. Rifts are tears in the dimensional fabric of Telara that spew out monsters from other planes - and fun events where you fight waves of enemies falling from the sky. They're what makes RIFT what it is.With low specs, lack of "pay to win" features, interesting story, and fun monster-fighting events, you'd think I'd recommend this game. Well... No. Most of the gameplay (not including rifts of course) is actually pretty dull. I would like to know what an Ascended warrior fighting against the game's equivalent of demons is doing picking mushrooms.I tried out the Autumn Harvest event, as I was bored with the regular gameplay. It was actually a bit of a disappointment - the usual dull grinding, except this time you're given the quests by a devil-like creature in a tiny orange clearing. I was hoping for a Hallowe'en themed rift.In short, the game is for the most part dull grinding with few rewarding areas, although the Devs throw a lot of free stuff at players. I would not recommend using your hard drive space on this game unless you don't mind hours of mindless grinding.

content:
ber 27, 2015
												So here i am again... thought ill reinstall and see if things got better, some stuff fixed, optimized.But reading the reviews, that's not the case.Won't reinstall and obviously wouldn't suggest to.Its your typical F2P game, you can (and must if you want to stay fully F2P) sink loads of hours into it, grinding different currencies, daily missions and so on.You can also use the auction house to aquire enough standard currency to buy shop services from other players.Or you can just pay for it in real money.There is nice features, like instant adventures and random groups for instances.The style and design ist bizarre in the nightmare areas, very funny if you like that, i did.The mission system is a bland "fetch x amount of this", "kill x amount of that", "talk to person x".As such the game is nicely done, don't get me wrong.I sank a lot of hours into it and most of them were fun.But much of it wasn't fun and with time that part becomes bigger and bigger.The grinding becomes soo very grindy.And if you don't want to spend hundreds of bucks on this, you will have to farm the daily and weekly missions on a regular basis... soo tedious, like having to go to work every day.The FPS drops in populated areas are ridiculous: 10 FPS for a lot of people... constant complains about it in chat.With the FPS issues come lag spikes and disconnects... lots of them.The anti hack measures regularilly mix things up, many people need to ask for confirmation emails to unlock accounts on a regular basis - many email providers in europe autoflag those mails from this specific company as spam or even won't let them through in any case.These issues have never been openly aknockledged let alone adressed by the devs while i was there.As a result the general mood between players and staff was asinine last time i played.Add to that, the fact it is rather old now... only the starter areas and the endgame areas are populated, in between it feels almost like a single player game.And it is in that stage of an F2P that i'd call the harvesting cycle.Money is made, by offering the same mount like last week - but this time in blue instead of red.... isn't that sweet?Real new content is only reluctantly added, so the long term players won't run away, and this content is implemented in a glitchy manner.Be aware, that after a steam download, you will require a lenghty update download from the games website.

												F2P? Not anymore... While technically you can spend 100s of hours grinding to buy the SP exansion, you can no longer do anything without it. Yes, there are still are still things you can do F2P, mostly solo now as everyone who still plays has moved onto SP.Yes, you can still PVP but you get matched against xpac players so you can't really do anything because the bolstering system is broken. You are probably wondering why I am complaining about the grind when Nightmare Tide was worse? Well everything about Nightmare Tide were small modular grinds that when paced right don't feel like a grind at all. SP is just a straigh up $40 grind to continue having any fun in the game.I don't know if SP is any good but if you are planning on playing this game without paying you have to grind so much that you will get burnt out before getting there.If you are the type that doesn't mind paying for games, I think you are better off with Newer, more populated games at this stage...Sorry if this seems like a rant, I'm sad that a great game has been ruined by being locked behind a paywall.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 4
												RIFT in and of itself is a decent game. However, there's some things about it that make it really hard to recommend.Pros: - Graphics are relatively good (better than Everquest 1/World of Warcraft but not as good as Elder Scrolls Online)- Invasions are a regular thing that can take over a zone and kill quest NPC's. In some cases you have to participate in the invasions to get them out of your way to do other quests.- Content is split up into solo content (open world), group content (mostly instanced things) and raid content (instanced with a few in the open world)- in group or raid content only 1 person has to enter the instanced and it'll offer to pull everybody else in the group or raid into the instanced as well.- Once you ignore somebody it ignores their entire account (the character, any name changes and all present/future characters on the account)- The wardrobe system is awesome. Whenever you achieve a weapon or armor graphic by having an item in your inventory it's added to a permanent account-wide list. From this list you're able to choose what weapon and armor graphics you want your character to have. - Guild quests are an interesting concept that I haven't seen in any other game. The fact that your entire guild can be sent on 1 objective is a cool idea. The perks gained from leveling your guild up through these quests also can increase quality of life greatly in game.Cons:- On the note of invasions they can also be a con because they kill quest NPC camps. Sometimes there can be so many invasion mobs in one camp that it looks like a herd of cattle except their all stacked on top of each other.- The community. A good portion of the community has made it to my ignore list due to how they act in groups, PVP or in general chat. On the bright side, the game seems more pleasant when you get all the bad apples on ignore.- To do random dungeons to get the daily reward bonuses you HAVE to have a full group. Therefore even though it would probably be possible for me and 2 buddies to complete a dungeon we still have to get into queue and gather 2 more people.- Dailys and Weeklys. You find yourself doing the same 10 repetitive quests because that's how you receive currency to achieve new armor/weapons. Somebody once asked me in a group what they missed because they've been gone 7 months from the game. I responded with "about 7 months worth of dailys". - The wardrobe system also has some downsides. To get all of the graphics for armor and weapons you, in theory, have to do raids as well. Some of the raids require a number of people to even enter the instanced even though the content itself would otherwise be soloable in future expansions.

content:
ber 14, 2016
												As someone with over 500 hours in this game, I think I'm qualified to say it's worth your time. Is there a lot of grinding in the end-game? Yeah, there is. But there's grinding in any MMO with end-game content. It's unavoidable. That being said, end-game will be the only thing you're grinding for. There's no grinding before you hit 65. And the leveling/questing process is one of the best I've ever seen in an MMO. I should also mention that dungeons/raids/pvp aren't the only end-game, either. There's amazing new questing zones once you hit 50, and all the current expansions are free and will remain free (though the new expac will be buy to play).As for earring slots, they ARE pay walled. BUT, you CAN buy them if you grind out 50k voidstones (which, honestly, isn't that hard). Some of the souls are also pay walled, but any extra souls are just fluff. This game is not, and never will be, pay to win.

content:
2014
												This free to play gem is a wonderful addition to anyone's library (hell it's free and worth your time to at minimum check out).  The core mechanics of the game are fine tuned and honed to the point where they deserve to unthrone the other kings in the MMO realm (looking at you World of Warcraft).  The free to play system does not sway into pay to win, and actually overall has improved the quality of the game from when it was subscription based (I played for 4 months at release).  The graphics in the game are of high quality, but not to the point where it takes the rig of God to run it.  The environment is well done and captivating.  The soundscape is something I was very impressed with ...  from the music to the combat sounds to the dialogue (it isn't overloaded with dialogue thank god) it all sounds just right enough to help immerse you in the game.  The combat mechanics and skill trees have been very fine tuned since the initial release.  They have become quite a charm.  The about of talent customization you can have in this game is....jaw dropping and awesome - an MMO theory crafters dream come true (I happen to be one).  Controls are as most 3d MMO's go, and is straight forward.  The UI is good, and there is a fair amount of UI customization mods available on curse.  I recommend this game for anyone seeking a good RPG or MMO that doesn't want to pay a lot of money, or any at all.

content:
er 25, 2013
												RIFT is a solid alternative to World of Warcraft. I've tried other free-to-play MMOs (Tera to name one), but they felt really linear and they wern't structured that well (if that makes any sense). Not RIFT. This game has everything you'd expect from an MMO. Dungeons, various PVP battles, and (my favorite thing about RIFT) RIFT has A LOT of world wide random events that encourages every player to come together and conquor. RIFT is by no means a pay-to-win game either. Everyone has access to everything. The only limitations free-to-players have is only having two character slots, a currency cap of 2500 platinum (which is a lot), and not being allowed to create auctions (which may sound bad to some, but there's trade chats, no player-to-player trading restrictions, plus you can earn that privilage by buying REX from players with in game currency). I highly, hightly encourage you to at least try it.

content:
2015
												RIFT is a MMORPG kind of game . As in all RPGs, the player assumes the role of a character. In RIFT, powerful rifts threaten the entire world as they rip into reality and release powerful forces that threaten to devastate all of Telara. New characters, events, treasures, and more are introduced with each breach and rift. The world is consistently changing around you and is dynamic.The rifts have created divisions and schisms among the Telarans. Players are given the option to either seal the rifts forever or to use the power of the rifts in order to create their own power.Thus, it is your choice to follow the one of the two rival factions, that, both want to save the world, but with their own unique way. Guardians are the chosen of Telara's gods, the Vigil. When the tyrant Aedraxis called forth the power of the Plane of Death and devastated Telara, the Vigil chose the most powerful souls taken by the Shade to be the archons of the next age. A golden age awaits, but Telara must first be saved — by deed, by example, or by the sword. Its people must be redeemed, its corruptors cleansed. Only then will the Guardians be imbued with the divine and ascend to a higher level.The Defiant do not care whether the gods abandoned the world or not. To them, this entire planar convergence disaster is the gods' fault in the first place. Indeed, as soon as things went from bad to worse, the gods suddenly and inexplicably disappeared. Instead the defiants worship machines and technology.Enough with the lore, now onto gameplay. RIFT™ has both PvE (Player vs Environment) and PvP (Player vs Player) systems. In each mode, players attempt to uncover the secrets of the planes. The game also features an innovative new class system, called "The Ascended " that has limitless possibilities to build and advance your character. The player chooses a soul from one of the four callings: warrior, cleric, rogue or mage. These initial souls begin weak, though as the player progresses so does the soul. As these souls become more specialised, the player will be weaker in for example combat, but will gain magic strength. Players can later choose to augment, or even replace, embraced souls with other souls from within their calling. This is called "Soul Attunement".As far as content go, I mentioned PvE And PvP content. PvE content consists of Dungeons, Raids, and - what else - Rifts. Rifts are a main feature in the game "Rift". Rifts appear first as tears in the fabric of Telara, and eventually fully open on their own. They can also be opened using a Planar Lure. Dungeons are instanced areas designed for a group of 5 players to complete. Players can create their own groups or find other players through the looking for group tool. Raids are instanced areas designed for groups of 10 or 20 players to complete. All raids are designed for level 65 (At the time of composing this) characters. PvP content consists of battlegrounds called Warfronts that are tiered by level, and conquest, a huge scale battlefront consisting of three factions striving to conquer the zone.

content:
16, 2016
												I am very difficult when it comes to MMORPG. Don get me wrong WOW apart from the cartoonist graphics has put the bar way way high when it comes to game play and everything else. Problem is that after 7 years of gaming and a ton of money i decided i won't play games with a monthly subscription. I want either free to play games or just buy to play games. After wow it was so hard to find an MMORPG game and i was looking around for months trying all the free to play games or at least free to try games. I wanted a game with a great content , good community and game play like wow but with different elements and different if not better graphics.I found Rift and i tried it. At first it felt a bit strange compared to wow although very similar. I loved the graphics and the game play so i continued (It is free anyway so nothing to lose apart from some of my free time). The more i played the more i loved it until i fell in love with it. Overall it is a great game and it can be perfect. What i didn't like to the point that i can say i hate about it is   first the macro thing. I was used to play wow with just 3 to 5 keys where i had all my rotations. Here you can't do that . Now about the money. It is a fact that if you want the dlcs or the extra packs you have to pay alot money. This things are overpriced. It is also bad marketing. A gamer that respects himself won't pay that money. For example i see that the DLC is about 30 euro and the packs start from 25. If i am going to pay 30 Euro i am expecting not only few more classes. i am expecting a new race, at least 5 more lvls , and new content with at least 10 new dungeons and raids. a DLC or a PACK the way they are in rift shouldn't cost more than 9.99.To tell you the truth they should be 4.99 . And guess what! The company would make more money like this cause almost everyone could and would buy then. More people would start the game and less people would quit. For 30 to 50 euro i am not expecting a pack or a DLC i am expecting a new game or at least a really good and huge expansion .So as not to get me wrong or cheap .I am 41 and spending 50 or 100 or even more for my hobby is nothing but i am expecting equal value. Today i log in to steam feeling i want to spend  money on a new game or on an old one. This review came from a man that 9 months ago spent 4.000 euro for a new desktop pc and hotas joystick and pedals just to play Star Citizen. I am angry and sad about Rift because i love it and want to continue play it and see more people play it . In order to have that , The company has to start giving value back for the money they want. Content people !!! CONTENT, make the customers happy. Make things cheap so people will be happy to throw some money for value at you. Today as i sead i wanted to really spend some money in to Rift. Call it shopping therapy if you want, so i logged in to the store looking the DLC and the packs, comparing them looking at the price and the value i am gona get and i didn't buy anything because i was disappointed.I appreciate the fact that it is a free game and people especially younger people that don't have money to spend can enjoy the game up to a good point. I was more than happy to spend about 50 euro so far progressively as i was getting to know the game for things like earring slots, extra bug slots, extra char slots and staff. I was happy to give back to you in the form of money the enjoyment i was getting and i want to continue give you money. I mean 750 happy hours for 50 euro is nothing. Plz help me and give me reasons to give you more money. Revive the game, add meaning full contend and price it low so all that can pay will buy it. The rest wont anyway.Maybe i got it all wrong and you are progressively making content and soon more lvls and continents and dungeons and all that and that content will be for free and for everyone and in that case i am sorry cause i got it wrong but still for the 30 euros you could add a new race for example. Anyway Right or wrong i had to take everything out of my chest.Overall it is a great game and you know what ..now that i am thinking about it i feel alot better and will go back in to the steam store and find a way to spend money in Rift . It might be the DLC or a pack or in game currency as a thank you for everything i got for free so far. Maybe we the people with money to spend can help you keep it free for the people without money.

content:
13, 2011
												Rift at it's heart feels like a complete and informed reworking of warhammer age of reckoning. The rift system is very similar to the public quests however they spawn randomly, are elementaly based, and tie into larger invasions where swarms of monsters wander around a map and it takes raids of people to clean it up! The class system is extremly open, there being 4 classes with each one having 8 diffrent trees (similar to a single tree in wow) that you can mix and match to have 3 trees at once. Healing mages, tanking rogues/clerics, an amazingly nice looking world, mixed with some top notch content for a new game. Once you reach lvl 20 is where the real pvp and instances begin, expect a new instance every 4 levels, then once you reach max lvl progress in heroic instances and raids, or work on lvling up your pvp rank. Rift is a fresh face in the mmo market and welcomly accepts the old style of plays into it, taking heavily form warhammer and wow but doing so with style and effect.

Not only do you earn abilities by picking talents in the tree, you also earn abilities by just putting points into the tree, abilities that are game changers.With SO many choices for each class it makes it hard for you to have a set ONE that everyone follows. Personal favorite is the assassin for the rouge class.With a support role added, it adds a whole new sense to raids and dungeons. They can switch between healing and damage with one button making them very universal for all instances.Over-all a very well made game, esspecially for being F2P.Seems rare now days for a game to be built for the gamers!

												After so much time spent in the game I finally drow the line... The thing that drove me here in the first place was the diversity in class system. It offered so much possibilities and promissed that you'd never run into another player with same skill set as you... but not anymore.Game before:-Huge open world to explore-Many interesting zone events-Many ways to make a skill build-Interesting and challenging dungeons and raidsGame now:-New expansion brought a new piece of land (a comet; even though it doesen't look and feel like one) and you have 4 and a half zones to explore (after 5 months in the expansion 1 zone is still not finished)-Zone events are repetitive and the same in every piece of land (kill 100 invasions, close 6 rifts and kill boss)-The game forces you to make certain builds (hybrid builds unusable anymore; tanks that don't make a build in a certain way get one-shotted by the raid boss)-4 dungeons (2 new, 2 old, rehashed ones), "expert" difficulity is too easy to do and one dungeon is still broken with no fix for 5 months, 1 "raid" (it is actually a 10 man expert dungeon if you compare how "hard" it is with no trash mobs) and one old raid in the making that will come out some day (no one knows when)If you are planing to play this game, DON'T. It's not worth it.The dev team doesen't know what they are doing it seems. Bugs everywhere (bugs discovered on Public Test Server weren't fixed and ended up on live server), skills unbalanced (will probably never be balanced), the game crashes even on high end machines... Simply stay away.P.S. Stay away from the forums for this game as well. Forums are highly moderated in the way that any kind of criticism is severly dealt with (any kind of criticism).

content:
ber 22, 2015
												I'm a returning player.  Bought the game in 2011 and quickly leveled a rogue soul to 50 back then, maxed crafting to 300.  At some point, got bored and quit and went on to other games as happens in this industry.  And then it surfaced as a "free to play" MMO in my Steam queue.  I'm so glad that it did.  I decided to check it out and I'm hooked all over again.  Just a few bullet points for the returning players / original box set purchases on what you'll find:- All my characters were on the trial server.  Easily transferred to a "real" server.- If you purchased a box set back in the day, you've already unlocked some of stuff new players have to pay for.  Namely, a few extra character slots, auction house access, extra bag slots.  That was nice to find out.-  Graphics have been much improved.  I logged in once before this and thought, no way, graphics are too dated.  Well, at some point along the line, they did a major overhaul.  It looks nice.  Could still use some optimization, won't lie.  I had to bring my settings down some and my machine is not a slouch.  But neverthless, still looks good.Here's what they have added off the top of my head since I played:-  Instant Adventures:  Think instant raids that level you quickly and give you quick coin.  If you don't relish the thought of leveling all over again, this is the way to level up quickly.  It's also a way to get a "dungeon group" of sorts since noone really does the dungeons actually in the game anymore.  Scales to your level starting from level 10.-  Minions.  New collectibles that go out and run adventures for you and bring back loot.  Sort of a card game as well.-  Costumes.  Unlock costume items as you find them and now make your character look how you want no matter what he/she is actually wearing (I love this, won't lie).-  Diminsions - Housing essentially.  You get a personal house and your guild can purchase one.  You can purchase diminsion items to decorate and your minion can go on missions to find items as well.-  Chronicles / Planar attunement - Honestly, no idea yet since this is all stuff you do with your character post level 50 and I actually started a new character to refresh my memory on how to play this game again. :P  I have looked it up and it seems as if it's a way of customizing your character even further however.At any rate, yes, the standard "pay" features are in this game as any:- Pay for extra soul walks or wait for a cool down.- Pay for extra bags- Pay for additional soulsAnd so forth.  But they are not as obtrusive as other games.  And frankly, I've already purchased the $24.00 add on pack and might consider others in the future.  I like the game that much again.

content:
, 2015
												One of the best MMORPGs hands-down.I've mainly played this outside of Steam (hence the low playtime), but the depth and level of customization that RIFT gives you for your class is incredible, and blows WoW out of the water. Sure, other things (like the dungeon experience imo) are better in WoW, but RIFT compensates with lots of really cool smaller features that add up quickly. For example, if you outlevel a dungeon/zone, but want to go back and grab the quests, you can set your 'mentored level' down, which essentially allows you to temporarily lower your character's level at will. Player housing is also present, and you can view other player's intricate designs on persistent leaderboards based on user votes.Combat is similar to other ability based RPGs, such as WoW, with the exception on the level of freedom that you get to design your own class. You can manually choose all your abilities from a set of about 10 talent trees (called 'souls') for each class, of which you can have 3 active at once. This means that almost every class can fill almost every role (DPS, tank, support, healer), and you can save your ability sets to allow you to change between roles on the fly (eg DPS → healer), giving each character a lot of versatility. Note that as this game is now free-to-play, some souls are locked behind a paywall, although at £15 if you shop around, it isn't too bad.Moving onto the game's implementation of free-to-play, you can easily complete the game (and the expansions – which are free to access) without paying anything, with all the in-game shop stuff being optional. If you do subscribe (£8.99/month last time I looked), you get the usual XP boosts etc that you would expect from a sub to a free MMO. A nice change however is the fact that the game was originally designed to b pay-to-play, so all the quests and story etc is scaled to those at 100% XP rate – subscribing just allows you to skip out parts as you see fit (and the XP boost can be toggled off). This is a nice change from other games like SWTOR, which feels like it's the subscribers that are getting the 100%, with the free players left at about 75%.Overall, it's a solid offering from Trion, which I feel is equal to, and better than is some cases, WoW.

content:
24, 2014
												What is RIFT?  Pretty much a FTP WoW, but without some of the annoying crap.  Like playing the MMOs, but also like to do a lot of soloing?  This is for you.  I personally did not care for WoW's dungeons due to the pettiness.  Here, RIFT forces some group play via randomly (and constantly) spawning Rifts on the main board.  Join group, close Rifts, kill mega-boss, collect loot.  No gripping, whining or trolling. Then go back your soloing.For those enjoying dungeon crawls/raids and are not anti-social, the dungeons are fun and sprawling.  The final bosses have unique game mechanics and good loot drop.  The dividing is based on the roll-need-greed system.Trade-chat.  It is what it is.Is it really FTP?  Yes.  You can buy cosmetics, pets and unique rides, but most of these can also be bought for platinum.  The only thing I am disappointed about is that you need to buy into the Auction House to sell items, or buy REX off the auction house to open it up.  Really though, it's only $5 (USD), ordyou can earn the plat and buy REX, which with some creative mat gathering won't take forever.TL;DR:  Free except auction house.  solo-friendly.

												  Great game overall, the community is well behaved, and Trion are some great guys. With the return of Hartsman, I'm sure this game has a bright future ahead. That said, It's been awhile since I've played. I played back at the release of the game and cleared through majority of the content at release in around 100 hours.  If you're looking to go far in this game, like most MMOs you will need a guild to get you through to the end. I'd definitely reccomend something organized, with a website, raid times, DKP, etc. There are a FEW people in the game that will try and spoil things for everyone with trying to ninja loot, or screw up quest lines. Though like most games, the rating changes based on the online play - I would never rate a game based on the community, but rather the support of the game by the developers and the amount of content available. Since I've played they've added a lot to the game. If you're looking for an MMO to spend an ample amount of time on, check this game out! :)

content:
ry 26, 2014
												Listen to me very carefully before you think all im going to do is praise this game just because i give it a thumb up. This game has a lot of faults, yet at the same time it does a lot of things correctly as well. Not specific enough? Well lets get specific. The good things? It is fun, the grind isn't bad at all - you can literally get to level 50 in 1-2 weeks without even noticing it - and still get good gear provided you know what you're doing. (If you pvp, do warfronts, and you'll get plenty of pvp gear.) PVP is very accessible - it doesn't require you get the best gear on the right away. PvE is very fun as well, and is diverse provided you're progressing at a good rate.Now comes the bad stuff. For me this game got old really fast at level 49. I didnt bother to do quests because, well, i was already outleveling them because i was pvping. (Although you could de-level by mentoring and do them to get a 'challenge.')  Additionally, this game is not rewarding. The loot is terrible most of the time - and if you're pvping you'll never ever use it simply because you'll probably have enough 'favor' (ingame currency) to buy better rift store gear, and as another addition, the auction house is locked down until you've managed to either shell out five bucks, or get a rift-exchange in order to get 1500 credits.Now the AH and pvp doesnt make the game. There's a lot i didn't see, and a lot i didn't get to do. Among more pros, the classes are diverse, and you can play more than one role, making switching 'easy-as-pie' if you want to try something else. But for me, the game got repetetive, and in the end, despite the innovations, still reeked of the deriviative mmo-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t most mmo games tend to smell of nowadays anyway. Not much new. However, still gets a 'recommended' simply because its enjoyable.To sum it up.PROSGood and diverse classes. Easy to play multiple roles.Diverse PvE content.PvP can be fun, and is easy to get into.Something i did not mention - Professions are enjoyable.The grind is barely noticable. (Until 50-60)CONSLoot is a joke, and the rift store reflects on this, making this game absolutely unsatsifying in some instances.Gets repeteive.AH is locked for selling (You can still buy.) down unless you shell out 5 bucks, or save a bunch of ingame currency to buy a rift exchange. (rex)Overall, good mmo, but has its fallbacks.

content:
15, 2014
												RIFT - a great option for MMO players. Great graphics, beautiful and detailed landscapes. You can customize your character the way you want to by using different souls available within your selected class. For example, take a bit of Pyromancer for offense, a lot of Elementalist for some serious pet capability, and some Chloromancer to heal the party. Rift also has several pre-built options for those who like to get in and play quickly. Beyond all of the systems in the game, the standard things about the game are also very well done. The audio is phenomenal, and the controls are pretty intuitive. Glitches are very infrequent, and minor anyway. Besides, the game is still fairly new so such things are to be expected. Leveling up in this game is not grindy at all. The game frequently keeps you on quests (storyline and otherwise) which level you up as you play the game, rarely (if ever) forcing you to pull off to the side for some time to just level up. The solo-play material is well-handled, as is the group-play material. Gameplay is mostly solid, and the freedom to progress however you wish is definitely a bonus. The quests could benefit from more variety – something Trion should keep in mind for future content updates – and the overarching story is easily lost beneath the endless strings of ‘Collect this!’ and ‘Kill those!’ If you go in expecting total originality, immediate disappointment is sure to follow, but spend some time with the game, and you’ll be impressed with what Trion has to offer. Rift breathes new life into the genre, restoring otherwise tired old concepts and proves success isn’t always built on originality.

content:
1
												Horribly overpriced for what you get. ALOT of grind for tokens, reputations and such before you even can get into the core of the game. Without paying for that grind you basically have to be unemployed to have the time. Gets small constant update but it's all cosmetics usually like new mounts that you have to play up to 20$ for (and some are just remakes with new colors). New raid gets released a few times a year but all it does is make your gear obsolete so you have to start over from zero again. Community is your standard toxic and elitism, although you can find a new player friend guild and enoy it at your own pace. On the good side I think the core of the game is quite good, I love the classic skill system where you can customize your characther tot the max, eventho there will always be a "best meta". The class variation is also good and each class has a different feel for it (Melee, Ranged, Magic, Healer or Tank). The PvE is quite good and if you've played WoW you'll find yourself almost as home. I'd play this game 100% of my spare time if I didnt have to spend almost 100$ / month to stay competetive (this is after the monthly patron payment). In it's current state I'd advice you to stay away until they lower prices, alot, and even remove some of the pay walls.

												From launch through the first year of free-to-play, the game was a joy: beautiful scenery, well-executed dynamic content, and lots to do from pvp to dungeons to fun open world to chasing artifacts.In the last year, however, it has steadily gone down hill as the publisher has squeezed the screws to harvest more money from the players and the somewhat old engine has become decidedly creaky with poor frame rate, frequent crashes, and very annoying visual bugs. The latter is probably also money related since it appears they have cut developer staff to the bone and they can't afford or choose not to invest further in the core engine.It is free to play, so you can get a taste of it at little risk but not likely to be a long term game for anyone these days.

content:
r 26, 2014
												Having logged 700+ hours on my old account, I installed it on this one simply to write this review. And I can safely say this is the best F2P MMORPG you will ever play.Pros:1) Even though the combat is tab target, it manages to retain aq dynamic feel. All your skills work together in some way so finding the perfect rotation is always interesting. Combat is also incredibly smooth and is really quite enjoyable.2) The Soul Tree system is perfect and will find a way to fit your play style effortlessly. You can even have custom classes unheard of in most any other game. A mage that doubles as a tank? If you want. A warrior with group healing? Go for it. A cleric with insane DpS? Hell yeah!3) PvP is AMAZING. I really can't expand on this any more. Try it for yourself. There is very rarely two players using the same build as there are so many possibilities. Endless fun :D4) The game has a solid storyline that really engages the players. You feel compelled to continue with the main quest line, although that shouldn't deter you from doing as many side quests as you wish. Quests have decent rewards, such as new equipment and a massive pile of cash. 5) Leveling up isn't a huge grind. Granted, there is some grinding to get new equipment or to get PvP gear. But unlike most, it isn't the same quest in the same area over and over again. The quests can be in different areas, and different objectives. Cons:1) Dungeons and monsters can get fairly tricky unless you keep on top of your equipment or have some fairly powerful friends. Join a guild for a group of regular party members.2) You need a hell of a computer to run this game on anything over medium graphics. I currently have an Intel i5, 8 GB of RAM and a Nvidia 640 GT and I can only run it on high at 50-60 FPS. For max you will really need good components. 3) If you don't pay for subscription, it doesn't affect anything a huge amount but you have a few restrictions that are kinda irritating.i) You can't buy or sell at the auction house. ii) Pretty small bag space. Probably most annoying.iii) It will take a LOT of grinding, however, to get a mount.Overall, a very fun, addictive, and engaging game. Definitly one you should get. It's polished and feels like a paid game. The highest praise a free game could have.
